Journal.Title: Rapid communications in mass spectrometry : RCM

Article.ArticleTitle: Measurement of <sup>18</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O and <sup>17</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O in atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> using the 253 Ultra mass spectrometer and applications to stratospheric and tropospheric air samples.

AbstractText: The doubly substituted isotopologues (e.g., <sup>18</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O, <sup>17</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O) in atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> are potential tracers for ozone photochemistry and atmospheric temperatures. Their low abundances and isobaric interference are the major analytical challenges. The 253 Ultra high-resolution stable isotope ratio mass spectrometer is suitable for resolving isobaric interferences.

O<sub>2</sub> from air is purified using gas chromatography on a packed column filled with molecular sieve 5 Å and cooled to -78°C. The δ<sup>17</sup> O, δ<sup>18</sup> O, Δ<sup>17</sup> O, Δ<sub>35</sub> and Δ<sub>36</sub> values are measured on the extracted O<sub>2</sub> with the 253 Ultra at medium mass resolution (M/ΔM ~10000) using Faraday detectors for the singly substituted isotopologues and ion counters for the doubly substituted isotopologues.

Interferences from isobars, mainly <sup>35</sup> Cl for <sup>17</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O and H<sup>35</sup> Cl and <sup>36</sup> Ar for <sup>18</sup> O<sup>18</sup> O, are sufficiently resolved to enable high-precision determination of Δ<sub>35</sub> and Δ<sub>36</sub> . The Δ<sub>35</sub> and Δ<sub>36</sub> values of O<sub>2</sub> after photochemical isotope equilibration at -63°C and heating to 850°C agree with the theoretical prediction. The stratospheric Δ<sub>35</sub> and Δ<sub>36</sub> values are close to isotopic equilibrium at the ambient temperatures. However, the values for tropospheric O<sub>2</sub> differ from those expected at equilibrium.

The 253 Ultra allows interference-free clumped isotope measurements of O<sub>2</sub> at medium mass resolution. The Δ<sub>35</sub> and Δ<sub>36</sub> signatures in atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> are mainly governed by O<sub>3</sub> photochemistry, temperature and atmospheric transport. Tropospheric O<sub>2</sub> is isotopically well mixed and retains a significant stratospheric signature.
